docs.snippet: Seeking to promote disarmament, leaders from northern Europe, the Balkans and the South Pacific today advocated banning nuclear weapons from their regions.   Karolos Papoulias, the Greek Foreign Minister, told the General Assembly: ''Greece has no...
docs.lead_paragraph: Seeking to promote disarmament, leaders from northern Europe, the Balkans and the South Pacific today advocated banning nuclear weapons from their regions. Karolos Papoulias, the Greek Foreign Minister, told the General Assembly: ''Greece has no illusions as to her power to influence international developments on a decisive scale. To this end, we are promoting the proposal to transform the Balkans into a nuclear-free zone.'' Mr. Paavo Vayrynen, Finland's Foreign Minister, said, ''Consolidating the absence of nuclear weapons from the territories of the Nordic countries through the establishment of a nuclear-weapons-free zone would make a signal contribution to stability.''

docs.snippet: When the Soviet Foreign Minister realized that he was going to be 12 minutes late for a noon meeting with the President of Uruguay, he was concerned that he might offend his host, who has a reputation for punctuality.   ''I have many things to...
docs.lead_paragraph: When the Soviet Foreign Minister realized that he was going to be 12 minutes late for a noon meeting with the President of Uruguay, he was concerned that he might offend his host, who has a reputation for punctuality. ''I have many things to criticize about the United States,'' Eduard A. Shevardnadze told President Julio Maria Sanguinetti as he apologized for his tardiness Monday. ''And today I add one more thing - traffic.'' Mr. Shevardnadze, who until 12 weeks ago was the Communist Party chief in Georgia, a non-Russian republic in the southern Soviet Union, is on his first trip to the United States, where he addressed the United Nations General Assembly today.

headline.main: NEW SOVIET FOREIGN MINISTER IS MAKING GOOD IMPRESSION AT U.N. ASSEMBLY

byline.original: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: A SUMMIT WARM-UP - The most discussed and most influential event at this year's General Assembly session is a meeting that will take place in Geneva, not New York. Thatis the meeting in November between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the...
docs.lead_paragraph: A SUMMIT WARM-UP - The most discussed and most influential event at this year's General Assembly session is a meeting that will take place in Geneva, not New York. Thatis the meeting in November between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader. The official warm-up begins today when Secretary of State George P. Shultz sits down with Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Soviet Foreign Minister, for a four-hour chat.

docs.snippet: Ten days ago Julio Cesar Lupinacci took over as Uruguay's representative at the United Nations and immediately faced a crisis: the visit of his country's President, Julio Maria Sanguinetti, who came to New York a few days later.   So daunting were...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ten days ago Julio Cesar Lupinacci took over as Uruguay's representative at the United Nations and immediately faced a crisis: the visit of his country's President, Julio Maria Sanguinetti, who came to New York a few days later. So daunting were the arrangements needed, Mr. Lupinacci recalled in an interview, that his seven mission staff members abandoned protocol and diplomatic hierarchy to prepare for the first visit ever of a Uruguayan president to the United Nations. While tending to such diplomatic duties as arranging Mr. Sanguinetti's overloaded schedule, Mr. Lupinacci also bought armchairs for the meeting room in the mission where the President would receive his guests. He sent his chauffeur, who was doubling as a typist, to the United Nations souvenir shop to buy tiny flag centerpieces representing the countries whose foreign ministers and heads of state Mr. Sanguinetti would be meeting. One of Mr. Lupinacci's junior diplomats canvassed limousine-rental companies to find the best price.

byline.original: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: In yacht racing, there are few challenges more arduous than the Whitbread Around the World Race. Yet 15 sailboats with international crews appeared ready for the task yesterday as the 1985-86 Whitbread fleet sailed from Portsmouth, England, for the...
docs.lead_paragraph: In yacht racing, there are few challenges more arduous than the Whitbread Around the World Race. Yet 15 sailboats with international crews appeared ready for the task yesterday as the 1985-86 Whitbread fleet sailed from Portsmouth, England, for the beginning of a 27,000-mile global voyage. Among them was Drum England, the 77-foot sloop owned by the British pop star Simon Le Bon of the rock group Duran Duran. It was the same boat that capsized off Britain Aug. 12 when the 14-foot keel of the newly built ocean racer dropped off in the middle of the Fastnet Race. The 24-man crew was rescued, including Le Bon, who had been one of six crew members trapped inside the overturned hull. Since then, Le Bon and his crew have scurried to get the boat ready for Whitbread, the race for which the boat was originally designed.

docs.snippet: When the armed forces stepped down in Argentina in December 1983, and in Uruguay 15 months later, the political parties of pre-coup days immediately reappeared, Congress came alive and something that could be recognized as the democracy of yore...
docs.lead_paragraph: When the armed forces stepped down in Argentina in December 1983, and in Uruguay 15 months later, the political parties of pre-coup days immediately reappeared, Congress came alive and something that could be recognized as the democracy of yore returned. But when 21 years of Brazilian dictatorship ended in March, neither the tradition nor the structure of party politics was ready to fill the vacuum. There was hardly a memory of democracy. Only Brazilians at least 45 years old could have voted for a President, and no pre-1964 parties survived.

docs.snippet: The Reagan Administration's decision to promote a new strategy to deal with Latin America's debt marks a turning point in the region's three-year-old financial crisis, foreign bankers and Government officials said here today.   They said Washington...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Reagan Administration's decision to promote a new strategy to deal with Latin America's debt marks a turning point in the region's three-year-old financial crisis, foreign bankers and Government officials said here today. They said Washington now accepted the Latin American argument that growth-oriented policies would enable the region to meet its huge debt obligations more effectively than the austerity programs demanded until now by the International Monetary Fund. The sources also noted that, in preparing an initiative to be announced in Seoul, South Korea, next week, the Administration had for the first time endorsed the principle that the governments of leading Western nations should play a direct role in easing the debt crisis. 'First New Approach' ''This is the first new approach that we've seen since the debt crisis began,'' one Brazilian official said. ''It's still too early to know whether it will be radical enough, but it nonetheless marks a significant shift in U.S. thinking.''

headline.main: U.S. SHIFT ON LATIN DEBT SEEN AS A TURNING POINT IN CRISIS

byline.original: By ALAN RIDING, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Following is the roll-call vote of 80 to 41 by which the United Nations General Assembly adopted a motion not to act on an amendment calling for the denial of the credentials of Israel. A vote in favor of the motion supported a Swedish-sponsored...
docs.lead_paragraph: Following is the roll-call vote of 80 to 41 by which the United Nations General Assembly adopted a motion not to act on an amendment calling for the denial of the credentials of Israel. A vote in favor of the motion supported a Swedish-sponsored proposal that no action be taken on the amendment, which was introduced by 18 Arab nations.

headline.main: U.N. ROLL-CALL VOTE ON EFFORT TO DENY CREDENTIALS TO ISRAEL

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: BYGONES The Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street (752-4690) is a small museum in size, but not in collection - a museum where artifacts wrap around spools and yet are ready to spring to life at the flick of a switch to resurrect the electronic...
docs.lead_paragraph: BYGONES The Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street (752-4690) is a small museum in size, but not in collection - a museum where artifacts wrap around spools and yet are ready to spring to life at the flick of a switch to resurrect the electronic past of radio and television. Today in the theater at 3 P.M., you can see Ernst Lubitsch's 1927 silent film, ''Old Heidelburg, or The Student Prince,'' with Ramon Novarro and Norma Shearer. Silent film in a broadcasting museum? The anachronism is explainable. This is part of a daily series, through Nov. 14, ''Television's Silents: Silent Films Newly Restored and Orchestrated for Television.'' The seven films in the series were rstored on videotape by Kevin Brownlow and David Gill, who edited them, reran them at proper speeds, added the musical accompaniment and are credited with helping restore them to favor with audiences via television in Great Britain.

docs.snippet: The United States Postal Service has announced that the new 18-cent coil stamp will feature a portrait of George Washington with the Washington Monument in the background. The first day of issue is Nov. 6 in Washington, D.C. Stamps will go on sale...
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States Postal Service has announced that the new 18-cent coil stamp will feature a portrait of George Washington with the Washington Monument in the background. The first day of issue is Nov. 6 in Washington, D.C. Stamps will go on sale across the country Nov. 7. The 18-cent denomination meets the basic presort rate for first-class letter mail. The design was unveiled Feb. 16 in Richmond, Va. At that time the stamp was expected to be released in July, but the heavy schedule of new issues this year resulted in its postponement. The George Washington portrait depicted is primarily based on a Gilbert Stuart painting. Since the Washington Monument was dedicated 100 years ago, its inclusion on this stamp is an appropriate gesture. This is the first stamp designed by Thomas Szumowski of Waltham, Mass.
